    Example to estimate incubation period

    Flavio Finger

    2019-02-19

    estimate_incubation.Rmd

    Description

    This package contains two functions useful to compute the incubation period distribution from outbreak data. The inputs needed for each patient are given as a data.frame or linelist object and must contain:

    • the date of onset of symptoms
    • a list/vector of possible dates of exposure.

    The function empirical_incubation_dist() computes the discrete probability distribution by giving equal weight to each patient. Thus, in the case of N patients, the n possible exposure dates of a given patient get the overall weight 1/(n*N). The function returns a data frame with column incubation_period containing the different incubation periods with a time step of one day and their relative_frequency.

    The function fit_gamma_incubation_dist() takes the same inputs, but directly samples from the empirical distribution and fits a discrete gamma distribution to it by the means of fit_disc_gamma.

    Example

    Load environment:

    library(magrittr)
library(linelist)
library(epitrix)
library(distcrete)
library(ggplot2)

    Make a linelist object containing toy data with several possible exposure dates for each case:

    ll <- messy_data() %>% clean_data()

x <- 0:15
y <- distcrete("gamma", 1, shape = 12, rate = 3, w = 0)$d(x)
mkexposures <- function(i) i - sample(x, size = sample.int(5, size = 1), replace = FALSE, prob = y)
exposures <- sapply(ll$date_of_onset, mkexposures)
ll$dates_exposure <- exposures

print(ll)
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition messy_dates
#> 1  zzhqmo    2018-01-08 2018-01-18   male            probable        <NA>
#> 2  bfecnq    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           suspected  2001-12-01
#> 3  mdhwnb    2018-01-02 2018-01-12   male           suspected        <NA>
#> 4  rswerl    2018-01-04 2018-01-14   male            probable        <NA>
#> 5  ffxbpa    2018-01-11 2018-01-21 female           suspected  2018-10-17
#> 6  snemgk    2018-01-05 2018-01-15   male            probable        <NA>
#> 7  mrolqi    2018-01-09 2018-01-19 female           suspected  2018-10-17
#> 8  vcvwlv    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           confirmed  1989-12-24
#> 9  wdfnvw    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           suspected  1989-12-24
#> 10 jtzxmi    2018-01-02 2018-01-12   male           confirmed        <NA>
#> 11 piqzli    2018-01-05 2018-01-15   male           suspected        <NA>
#> 12 uwdija    2018-01-02 2018-01-12 female           suspected        <NA>
#> 13 khaysl    2018-01-05 2018-01-15   male          not_a_case  2018-10-17
#> 14 engthy    2018-01-02 2018-01-12 female           confirmed  2018-10-18
#> 15 lipmkz    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           confirmed        <NA>
#> 16 cphrlq    2018-01-04 2018-01-14 female          not_a_case  1989-12-24
#> 17 yxwdrv    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           confirmed  2018-10-17
#> 18 xueswq    2018-01-03 2018-01-13   male           confirmed  2018-10-18
#> 19 toyvyc    2018-01-10 2018-01-20   male          not_a_case        <NA>
#> 20 rdorgf    2018-01-06 2018-01-16   male          not_a_case  2018-10-18
#>          lat      lon                    dates_exposure
#> 1  14.066098 48.22808 17536, 17534, 17533, 17535, 17537
#> 2  13.354656 46.13320               17532, 17533, 17531
#> 3  14.015094 49.52703 17529, 17528, 17531, 17530, 17527
#> 4  12.614052 48.73272        17532, 17533, 17530, 17529
#> 5   8.365155 47.14973        17540, 17533, 17537, 17538
#> 6  16.266679 48.78670        17534, 17533, 17532, 17531
#> 7  10.143683 48.79583               17535, 17536, 17538
#> 8  16.214524 47.08857                      17532, 17531
#> 9  12.419526 47.84464                             17531
#> 10 14.773045 47.58309                      17530, 17528
#> 11 14.225050 46.84521               17532, 17533, 17535
#> 12 12.666040 48.54203                      17529, 17528
#> 13 13.806735 45.23843               17530, 17532, 17533
#> 14 11.549467 47.34293 17531, 17529, 17527, 17530, 17528
#> 15 12.991996 49.24820                             17532
#> 16 11.690004 47.18760                             17533
#> 17 16.838650 47.76596               17530, 17531, 17532
#> 18 15.738192 48.83755 17531, 17530, 17529, 17533, 17528
#> 19 13.808738 47.86753        17540, 17536, 17538, 17537
#> 20 10.438206 47.99682 17531, 17535, 17533, 17534, 17532

    Empirical distribution:

    incubation_period_dist <- empirical_incubation_dist(ll, date_of_onset, dates_exposure)
print(incubation_period_dist)
#> # A tibble: 9 x 2
#>   incubation_period relative_frequency
#>               <dbl>              <dbl>
#> 1                 1             0.0392
#> 2                 2             0.236 
#> 3                 3             0.254 
#> 4                 4             0.196 
#> 5                 5             0.183 
#> 6                 6             0.0792
#> 7                 7             0     
#> 8                 8             0     
#> 9                 9             0.0125

ggplot(incubation_period_dist, aes(incubation_period, relative_frequency)) +
  geom_col()

    Fit discrete gamma:

    fit <- fit_gamma_incubation_dist(ll, date_of_onset, dates_exposure)
print(fit)
#> $mu
#> [1] 4.003347
#> 
#> $cv
#> [1] 0.3504702
#> 
#> $sd
#> [1] 1.403054
#> 
#> $ll
#> [1] -1740.383
#> 
#> $converged
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $distribution
#> A discrete distribution
#>   name: gamma
#>   parameters:
#>     shape: 8.14137544427614
#>     scale: 0.491728555465178

x = c(0:10)
y = fit$distribution$d(x)
ggplot(data.frame(x = x, y = y), aes(x, y)) +
  geom_col(data = incubation_period_dist, aes(incubation_period, relative_frequency)) +
  geom_point(stat="identity", col = "red", size = 3) +
  geom_line(stat="identity", col = "red")

    Note that if the possible exposure dates are consecutive for all patients then empirical_incubation_dist() and fit_gamma_incubation_dist() can take date ranges as inputs instead of lists of individual exposure dates (see help for details).
